description.narrative: Chimpanzee Conservation in Light of Impending Mining Projects in Southeastern Senegal

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Complete survey of chimpanzees outside of protected areas in Senegal: Filling gaps in our..knowledge in anticipation of corporate mining development.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to determine the presence and relative densities of chimpanzees in areas of southeastern Senegal to understand the impacts of proposed large-scale mining and to identify key habitats for future protection.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: CITES CoP17 coordination workshop between West and Central African countries and the United States

description.narrative: This grant will provide funding to Born Free USA to assist Senegal in facilitating the organization of a three day meeting between 20 West and Central African countries and the US Fish and Wildlife Service. Support provided to the West/Central African region for the organization of the meeting will include logistical assistance and support related to the development and translation of meeting documents including a draft enforcement declaration, draft listing proposals and draft working documents and any other document necessary to help build regional consensus. Discussion of meeting documents will be followed by discussions on the designation of specific issue leaders mandated by the region to take specific issues forward on the way up to and at CoP17. A section of the meeting will be devoted to building strategic alliances between the United States and countries in West and Central African countries on issues of common interest. The project team will also provide support to meeting participants designated as issue leaders on.specific issues after the meeting to assist with anything related to the submission of CoP17 documents. This project will be conducted as described in the Born Free USA grant proposal.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Coastal Senegal Sea Turtle Stranding Surveys to Assess mortality and nesting.

description.narrative: The recipient will conduct quarterly nesting and stranding surveys along Senegal's north coast from Dakar to St. Louis beginning in January 2016 by foot and vehicle. Additionally nesting and stranding surveys will be conducted south of Dakar for the remaining Senegal coastline 1-2 times during the year. Interviews will be conducted along the survey routes with local people to gather information about nesting and local fisheries interactions with sea turtles. The recipient will also conduct a public education campaign in Senegal to raise awareness of protected status of sea turtles and marine mammals as described in the proposal.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Assessing novel pathways of mercury bioaccumulation in West African chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes.verus) in Senegal

description.narrative: The purpose of this 2-year project is to assess the health risks that mercury usage associated with artisanal gold mining poses to western chimpanzees in Senegal. Activities include: 1) analyzing likely contaminated and uncontaminated soil and chimpanzee food samples; 2) establishing a cost-effective method of monitoring chimpanzee mercury exposure; 3) conducting a risk assessment of chimpanzee mercury poisoning; and 4) disseminating findings to the conservation community and the Senegal government to support possible mitigation actions.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: Assessing novel pathways of mercury bioaccumulation in West African chimpanzees in Senegal.

description.narrative: The goal of this proposal are to determine the extent to which Hg contamination is impacting importamt chimpanzee habitat (soil) and ffod sources (termites and vegitation) and to evaluate the level of exposure of chimpanzee populations via MeHg analysis of hair samples.
